isis.stitle: BRAKE COMPONENTS: This Service Manual Section should be used for reference only. For more current service information on all components go to the Bendix website from the ISIS Suppliers menu and refer to the Service Data Sheets. - BENDIX E6-TREADLE AND E7-SUSPENDED PEDAL TYPE (FOOT) BRAKE VALVES - SERVICING TREADLE TYPE VALVE

step1.para: Apply parking brake and block wheels.
Drain all air from all reservoirs.
Disconnect all supply and delivery lines at (foot) brake valve. Mark all air lines in relation to valve to assist when reconnecting lines.
Remove fittings from valve. Mark these fittings also in relation to location and position on the valve.
Remove (foot) brake valve and treadle assembly by removing three capscrews on outer bolt circle of mounting plate. Basic valve alone may be removed by removing three capscrews on inner bolt circle.

svcsubproc.title: Disassemble
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 25 for all items in parentheses.

step1.para: If the entire brake valve and treadle assembly was removed from the vehicle, remove the capscrews securing treadle assembly to the basic brake valve.
Remove screw (Item 19) securing the exhaust diaphragm (Item 17) and washer (Item 20) to exhaust cover (Item 16).
Remove four screws that secure exhaust cover (Item 16) to lower valve body (Item 23).

Remove secondary inlet and exhaust valve assembly (Item 14) from lower valve body (Item 23). Disassembly of secondary inlet and exhaust valve assembly is not required since it is only serviced as an assembly.
Remove four hex head capscrews securing the lower valve body (Item 23) to upper valve body (Item 24) and separate the bodies.
Remove the rubber seal ring (Item 13) from the lower body.
Apply thumb pressure to primary piston (Item 9), lift out and up on the three lock tabs of primary piston retainer (Item 26).

Use a 3/8 inch (10 mm) wrench to hold the nut on threaded end of stem on top of primary piston. Insert a screwdriver in exhaust passage through center of valve and engage slotted head of the stem (Item 27).

warning.para: Before proceeding, note the nut and stem are used to contain primary piston return spring (Item 25), stem spring (Item 4) and relay piston spring (Item 11). Combined force of these springs is approximately 50 ft-lbs. (68 Nm). Care must be taken to prevent personal injury when removing the nut as the spring forces will be released. It is recommended that primary piston and relay piston be contained while nut and stem are being removed.

step1.para: Rotate the screwdriver counterclockwise and remove stem (Item 27), stem spring (Item 4), spring guide (Item 3) and nut.
Remove relay piston (Item 12), relay piston spring (Item 11), primary piston (Item 9) and primary piston return spring (Item 25) from the upper body.
Disassemble primary piston (Item 9) by separating spring seat nut, spring seat (Item 6), rubber spring (Item 8) and removing piston O-ring.
Remove large and small O-rings from relay piston.
Remove retaining ring securing primary inlet and exhaust valve assembly (Item 10) in upper body and remove valve assembly. Do not disassemble primary inlet as it is only serviced as an assembly.

svcsubproc.title: Clean and Inspect
svcsubproc.para: Wash all metal parts in cleaning solvent. Use compressed air to dry parts. Inspect all parts for excessive wear or deterioration. Inspect valve seats for nicks or burrs. Check springs for cracks or corrosion. Replace all rubber parts and any part not found to be serviceable during inspection.

svcsubproc.title: Reassemble
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 25 for all items in parentheses.

Prior to reassembling brake valve, lubricate all O-rings, O-ring grooves, piston bores and metal-to-metal moving surfaces. Lubricate with Fleetrite EP2 Moly grease or equivalent to NLGI #2 multi-purpose lithium grease.
All torques specified are assembly torques and can be expected to differ after assembly is accomplished. Do not re-tighten nuts after initial torque is applied.

step1.para: Position primary inlet and exhaust assembly in the upper body; then install retaining ring to secure it. Be sure the retaining ring is seated completely in its groove.
Install large and small O-rings on relay piston.
Replace primary piston O-ring in piston O-ring groove.
Position rubber spring (Item 8), concave side down, in primary piston (Item 9) and place spring seat (Item 6), flat side up, over rubber spring.
Install primary piston spring seat nut (Item 5) with its hex closest to spring seat and rotate clockwise until top surface of spring seat is even with top surface of piston (Item 9).
Position primary piston return spring (Item 25) in the upper body piston bore.
Install primary piston, spring seat out, over return spring and press piston into body bore.
Place relay piston return spring (Item 11) in the upper body and position relay piston (Item 12) over spring so that the concave side of the piston is against the spring.
Place stem (Item 27) through exhaust passage of the lower body so that threaded portion is visible at primary piston.
Use a screwdriver to engage and hold the slotted head of stem; then position stem spring (Item 4) and spring guide (Item 3) over primary piston (Item 9).
Install nut on stem and rotate clockwise. Tighten to 20 to 30 in-lbs. (2.3 to 3.4 N· m).
Install primary piston retainer (Item 26) over piston making certain all three lock tabs have engaged the outer lip of body.
Install secondary inlet and exhaust valve assembly in lower body.
Place exhaust cover (Item 16) on lower body and install four machine screws with lockwashers; tighten to 70 to 100 in-lbs. (7.9 to 11.3 N • m).
Install exhaust diaphragm (Item 17) and diaphragm washer (Item 18) to exhaust cover (Item 16) using Phillips head screw and lockwasher.
Install seal ring (Item 13) in lower body and secure lower body to upper body using four hex head capscrews and lockwashers; tighten capscrews to 70 to 100 in-lbs. (7.9 to 11.3 N • m).
Install treadle valve assembly to basic brake valve. Secure with capscrews and lockwashers and tighten to 80 to 100 in-lbs. (9 to 11.3 N • m).

Test the rebuilt brake valve by performing
SERVICE CHECKS
.
